issues.description: The Solution's Animal constructor signature does not match the UML specification in the problem statement. The UML defines Animal(String, int) but the solution implements only Animal(String), so students cannot satisfy both the specified constructor and subclass constructors.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the Animal constructor in the solution to accept both a String name and an int age (and update subclasses accordingly) to match the UML, or revise the UML and tasks to require only a name parameter.

issues.description: The Solution's Animal class omits the 'age' attribute defined in the UML (int age) and does not provide its getter or setter, so the class structure diverges from the specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Add a private `int age` field to Animal and implement its getter and setter in the solution to align with the UML diagram.

issues.description: In the template, the private method singFarmSongVerse has its Animal parameter commented out, but the solution (and UML) expects `singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal)`. This mismatch will confuse students when wiring up the song method.
issues.suggested_fix: Uncomment and include the `Animal animal` parameter in the template's `singFarmSongVerse` signature to match the UML and reference solution.

issues.description: The sample Main code in the template uses single-argument constructors for Seal, Pig, and Goat (e.g. new Seal("Clarabelle")), but the UML defines Animal constructors with two parameters (String, int). This inconsistency between the UML and the provided example will confuse students about how to instantiate animals.
issues.suggested_fix: Either update the UML and tasks to use only a single-parameter constructor for each animal (String name) or change the example in Main to pass both name and age when creating animals.
